Award.AwardTitle: Optoelectronic Tweezers on Sapphire for Compact High Throughput Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorter

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Chiou, Pei-Yu
Institution: University of California-Los Angeles
Title: Optoelectronic Tweezers on Sapphire for Compact High Throughput Fluorescence Activated Cell Sorter



Intellectual Merit: High throughput single cell analysis is the future trend for quantitative biology. Florescence activated cell sorter (FACS) is the most powerful and gold standard tool for high speed and multi-parametric single cell analyses. It has broad applications from fundamental research in immunology, cell biology, molecular biology, to clinical applications, such as AIDS and cancer detection and analysis. However, the current FACS is bulky, expensive and requires well-trained technician to operate in a centralized facility. High performance and low cost FACS for applications in clinics and resource-limited areas are highly sought but have not been realized. Many microfluidic FACS systems have been proposed over the past ten years, yet sorting live mammalian cells at high speeds with high sort purity and high cell viability remains a major challenge and the integrated system is not compact. Bulky optics such as PMT tubes for optical detection, and bulky external fluid pumping systems for fluid delivery are the two major barriers for FACS miniaturization. This proposal aims to develop a compact and high throughput FACS enabled by a novel ultrahigh sensitivity optoelectronic tweezers (OET) fabricated on a transparent sapphire substrate. This platform provides millions of light-actuated single cell trapping wells to provide a high throughput single cell sorting based on multicolor fluorescence signals. The massively parallel OET enabled optical manipulation gives O-FACS a throughput of 55,000 cells/sec on a smartphone size system, a throughput equivalent to current high-end benchtop FACS systems.

Broader Impacts: The proposed compact, handheld, and high throughput O-FACS platform will provide paradigm-shifting impacts in cell sorting fields. It will have broad applications from fundamental biological research to clinical applications. Results and expertise developed during the course of this project will also be incorporated into the PIs? teaching activities at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Minority graduate and undergraduate students will participate in these projects through independent research courses. Students involved in this project will be exposed to an excellent multidisciplinary training environment in the UCLA Engineering School. The PIs will also be involved with the outstanding outreach program (CEED) in UCLA to recruit underrepresented college students for short-term project through the Introduction to Engineering Disciplines (E 87) course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

High throughput single cell analysis is the future trend for quantitative biology. Florescence activated cell sorter (FACS) is the most powerful and gold standard tool for high speed and multi-parametric single cell analyses. It has broad applications from fundamental research in immunology, cell biology, molecular biology, to clinical applications, such as AIDS and cancer detection and analysis. However, the current FACS is bulky, expensive and requires well-trained technician to operate in a centralized facility. High performance and low cost FACS for applications in clinics and resource-limited areas are highly sought but have not been realized. Many microfluidic FACS systems have been proposed over the past ten years, yet sorting live mammalian cells at high speeds with high sort purity and high cell viability remains a major challenge and the integrated system is not compact. Bulky optics such as PMT tubes for optical detection, and bulky external fluid pumping systems for fluid delivery are the two major barriers for FACS miniaturization.

Here we developed the novel Self-Locking Optoelectronic Tweezers (SLOT), which enables large-area single-cell and microparticle manipulations in cell culture media and introduce an original self-locking optical manipulation concept. SLOT is realized by laying out an array of ring-shaped, lateral phototransistor-based electrodes which resistance can be optically modulated. Without light illumination, single cells and microparticles are self-locked by DEP traps formed above the ring-shaped electrodes under proper voltage biasing. With light illumination, individual DEP traps are turned off to release the corresponding illuminated cells with the help of background fluid flow. Unlike conventional OETs, the trapping and optical releasing operations of SLOT are fully decoupled, which enables the deployment of a dense array of ring-shaped electrodes over a large area, offering potentially tens of cm2 of platform footprint to trap hundreds of millions of single cells. Although the field-of-view of optical illumination system remains restricted, the optical projection system can serially scan across the entire SLOT platform, like a lithography stepper in modern semiconductor foundry, to selectively release trapped cells and microparticles to form desired patterns across a large area.

Broader Impacts

The proposed SLOT platform provides paradigm-shifting impacts in cell sorting fields. It has broad applications from fundamental biological research to clinical applications.  Results and expertise developed during the course of this project were incorporated into PIs’ teaching activities at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Minority graduate and undergraduate students participated in these projects through independent research courses. Students involved in this project were exposed to an excellent multidisciplinary training environment in UCLA Engineering School.

Key Outcome Summary

We demonstrated a novel Self-Locking Optoelectronic Tweezers (SLOT) for single-cell and microparticle manipulation across an ultra-large area (>100 mm2) that can provide over 250,000 traps with each of them optically addressable. The unique self-locking mechanism allows single cells and microparticles to be locked in the dark state to resist a background microfluidic flow. This permits ultra-large-area single-cell and microparticle manipulation and patterning with high throughput in a stepper fashion. Furthermore, the single crystalline silicon-based phototransistors offer high photoconductive gain to permit cell manipulation directly in regular physiological buffers without periodic media change. Key contributions include:

1)      An unprecedented self-locking functionality for single cells and microparticles without light illumination is invented.

2)      A 100x larger active area for single-cell manipulation in physiological medium is demonstrated.

3)      Graduate student researchers have gained educational experiences through their research participations.
